captions.text: [ Elevator Bell Dings ]
lt was me !

Hi, Mr. Reede !
Like the new dress ?

Whatever takes the focus
off your head.

- What's up, Fletcher ?
- Your cholesterol, fatty !
Dead man walkin'.

- Hey, Fletcher.
- Hey ! You're not important
enough to remember.

- What's it gonna be, Mr. Reede ?
- A pockmark, eventually !

Don't ask !
For God's sakes, don't ask.

All right.
You can beat this.

lt's all a matter
of willpower !
A test. Something small.

Red. Red. All right ?
Now focus.

The color of this pen
is r-r-r--
The color of this pen...
iS le-e-e-e-e--
Re-e-e-e--

The color of the pen
that l hold in my hand...
iS l-l-l-l--
r-r-royal blue !
[ Yelps ]
One lie, and l can't say it !
l'll write it.
[ Yelling ]

Write it ! Write it,
or l'll break it off !
[ Chuckling Victoriously ]

Agh ! No !
Come on ! Stop it.
[ Screaming ]
Boss ? What happened ?

The pen is blue.
The pen is blue !
The goddamn pen is blue !

comments.author: NexisFilms

comments.text:
Here's a loophole to that: he could make it the truth by inventing a 
language in his own head.

Let's call it Pennish.

Here's the full Pennish-English dictionary:

thispenis /ðɪs.pɛn.ɪz/: w. Translates to the English sentence fragment "The 
color of this pen is"
red /rɛd/: w. Translates to the English word "blue"

Speaking in this language, but not verbally indicating so, would create 
ambiguity that would misdirect listeners into believing it is English, 
while simultaneously refraining from lying.

Say: "thispenisred"

Listeners will hear: "This pen is red!"

You have successfully loophole'd the "no lie" rule. The only catch is that 
if a listener asks you why you said this pen is red when it's clearly blue, 
you would be forced to say "That was me speaking in Pennish".﻿
